archimate:ArchimateDiagramModel.name: Network
archimate:ArchimateDiagramModel.documentation:
Network (<<Communication Path>>)
Description: Communication infrastructure connecting systems.
Examples:
• Hospital Wi-Fi networks • Secure clinical networks • Remote site connectivity • Telemedicine networking • Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) networks

children.name: Technology Layer
children.documentation:
Technology Layer
Network Infrastructure
Local Area Network (LAN)
Core Network
• Core Switches
o Function: High-capacity, high-performance network backbone
o Relationships:
 Connects to → Distribution Layer: At 10/40 Gbps  Connects to → Data Center Infrastructure: At 40/100 Gbps  Connects to → WAN: At 10/40 Gbps  Secured by → Firewalls: For network segmentation and security  Monitored by → IDS/IPS: For threat detection and prevention
• Router Cluster
o Function: Manages traffic between network segments, provides redundancy
o Relationships:
 Connects to → Core Switches: For internal routing  Connects to → Internet Gateway: For external traffic routing  Protected by → Firewalls: For security enforcement
• DC Interconnect
o Function: High-speed connectivity between data centers (main and DR) o Relationships:  Connects → Core Switches to Disaster Recovery: Ensures data replication path  Requires → Data Encryption: For secure data transfer between sites
Distribution Layer
• Distribution Switches
o Function: Aggregates connections from access layer, applies policies
o Relationships:
 Connects to → Core Network: Uplink at 10/40 Gbps  Connects to → Access Layer: Downlink at 1/10 Gbps  Implements → L3 Routing: For inter-VLAN routing  Connects to → Medical Network: Dedicated path at 10 Gbps
• L3 Routing
o Function: Handles routing between VLANs and network segments
o Relationships:
 Implemented on → Distribution Switches: For efficient traffic management  Protected by → Access Control Lists: For traffic filtering
Access Layer
• Access Switches
o Function: Provides connectivity to end devices and users
o Relationships:
 Connects to → Distribution Layer: Uplink at 1/10 Gbps  Connects to → Clinical Workstations, Medical Devices: User connectivity  Enforced by → Network Access Control: For device authentication
• PoE Switches
o Function: Provides Power over Ethernet for devices
o Relationships:
 Powers → Wireless Access Points, IP Phones, Security Cameras  Connects to → Distribution Layer: For network access
• Edge Computing Nodes
o Function: Provides localized computing resources near data sources
o Relationships:
 Connects to → IoT Devices: For local data processing  Connects to → Access Layer: For network connectivity  Feeds data to → Analytics Platform: For further processing
Medical Device Network
• Medical Device VLAN
o Function: Isolated network segment for medical equipment
o Relationships:
 Isolates → Medical Devices: For security and reliability  Connected to → Distribution Layer: Via dedicated 10 Gbps links  Protected by → Firewalls: For strict access control  Monitored by → IDS: For anomalous behavior detection
• Isolation Zones
o Function: Additional network segmentation for critical medical systems
o Relationships:
 Contains → Life-critical systems: Extra protection for most sensitive devices  Protected by → Specialized Firewalls: With medical device protocols awareness  Monitored by → SIEM: For compliance and security monitoring
Wide Area Network (WAN)
• Internet Gateway
o Function: Provides controlled access to/from the internet
o Relationships:
 Connects to → Core Network: For internal access to external resources  Controlled by → Firewalls: For security enforcement  Monitored by → IDS/IPS: For threat detection
• MPLS Network
o Function: Carrier-provided secure, reliable WAN connectivity
o Relationships:
 Connects → Main Hospital to Remote Clinics: Primary WAN connectivity  Protected by → Carrier Security: For data in transit protection  Monitored by → Performance Monitoring: For SLA enforcement
• SD-WAN Controllers
o Function: Software-defined WAN management for intelligent traffic routing
o Relationships:
 Manages → WAN connectivity: Optimizes traffic based on application needs  Provides → Failover: Secondary path if MPLS fails  Connects → Remote Clinics: Alternative connection method  Integrates with → Core Network: For seamless failover
• Internet Service Provider
o Function: Provides internet connectivity
o Relationships:
 Connects to → Internet Gateway: Primary external connectivity  Provides → Bandwidth for external services: Web access, cloud services  Monitored by → Performance Monitoring: For SLA enforcement
• Remote Access
o Function: Enables secure connections for remote workers
o Relationships:
 Secured by → VPN Services: For encrypted connections  Authenticated by → Identity Management: For user verification  Monitored by → SIEM: For suspicious activity detection
Wireless LAN (WLAN)
• Wireless Controllers
o Function: Centralized management of wireless access points
o Relationships:
 Manages → Access Points throughout facility  Connected to → Core Network: For management  Implements → Wireless Security Policies: For different wireless networks
• Access Point Management
o Function: Configuration, monitoring, security of wireless infrastructure
o Relationships:
 Controls → Access Points: For consistent configuration  Integrates with → Network Access Control: For device authentication  Monitored by → SIEM: For rogue AP detection
• Wireless Networks
o Staff WiFi
 Function: Secure wireless access for hospital staff
 Relationships:
 Used by → Clinical Staff, Administrative Staff  Secured by → WPA3-Enterprise, 802.1X Authentication  Connects to → Internal Resources: Via access control
o Guest WiFi
 Function: Internet access for patients and visitors
 Relationships:
 Used by → Patients, Visitors  Isolated from → Internal Networks: For security  Limited to → Internet Access Only: No internal resource access
o Medical Device WiFi
 Function: Dedicated wireless network for medical equipment
 Relationships:
 Used by → Mobile Medical Devices, Bedside Monitors  Connects to → Medical Device VLAN: For isolation  Prioritized for → Critical Medical Traffic: QoS implementation
o IoT WiFi
 Function: Network for connected non-medical devices
 Relationships:
 Used by → Building Automation, Environmental Monitoring  Isolated from → Clinical Networks: For security  Connects to → IoT Management Platform: For device management

children.name: Business Layer
children.documentation:
Hospital Campas Departments (Business Layer)
Hospital Campus (Physical)
The physical organization structure where healthcare services are delivered.
Main Hospital Building (Physical)
• Function: Primary facility housing most departments and services
• Relationships:
o Houses → Data Center: Contains the central IT infrastructure that powers all hospital operations o Contains → Various departments including Emergency and Radiology
Emergency Department (Floor 1)
• Function: Provides urgent and emergency care services
• Relationships:
o Served by → Emergency Management System (EMS): Uses specialized applications for patient tracking, triage, and emergency response management o Connected to → Core Network: Critical network infrastructure ensures high availability for emergency systems
Radiology Department
• Function: Performs diagnostic imaging services
• Relationships:
o Uses → Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS): For storing, retrieving, and sharing medical images o Uses → Radiology Information System (RIS): For scheduling, reporting, and workflow management o Connected to → Distribution Layer: Requires high bandwidth for transferring large image files
Admin Department
• Function: Provides administrative functions and services for hospital.
• Relationships:
o Uses → Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS): For storing, retrieving, and sharing medical images o Uses → Radiology Information System (RIS): For scheduling, reporting, and workflow management o Connected to → Distribution Layer: Requires high bandwidth for transferring large image files

children.name: Application Layer
children.documentation:
Application Layer
Clinical Applications
Electronic Health Record (EHR) System
• Function: Central repository for patient medical records and clinical documentation
• Relationships:
o Integrates with → PACS: For embedding medical images in patient records o Integrates with → RIS: For radiology reports and workflow o Runs on → VM Host Cluster: Virtualized for high availability o Backed up by → Backup System: For data protection and compliance o Accessed by → Clinical Workstations: Primary user interface for clinicians o Receives data from → Bedside Monitors: Automated integration of patient vitals o Secured by → Identity Management: For proper access control o Protected by → Data Encryption: For PHI security compliance
Radiology Information System (RIS)
• Function: Manages radiology workflows, scheduling, reporting
• Relationships:
o Integrates with → EHR: Shares radiology reports with patient records o Integrates with → PACS: For image workflow management o Used by → Radiology Department: Primary users of the system o Runs on → VM Host Cluster: For reliability and performance
Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS)
• Function: Stores, retrieves, presents, and shares medical images
• Relationships:
o Stores data in → Storage SAN: Requires large storage capacity for images o Integrates with → EHR: Makes images available in patient records o Used by → Radiology Department: Primary system for radiologists o Requires → High Bandwidth Network: For transferring large image files
Emergency Management System (EMS)
• Function: Manages emergency department workflows, triage, bed tracking
• Relationships:
o Serves → Emergency Department: Tailored for ED operations o Integrates with → EHR: Shares patient data o Runs on → VM Host Cluster: For high availability o Requires → Low-latency network: For real-time updates
Telehealth Platform
• Function: Enables virtual patient consultations and remote care
• Relationships:
o Accessed by → Mobile Devices: For healthcare provider remote access o Integrates with → EHR: For patient record access during telehealth visits o Requires → WAN connectivity: For remote access from various locations o Protected by → Security Services: For compliance with healthcare privacy regulations
Administrative Applications
Hospital Information System (HIS)
• Function: Manages administrative aspects of hospital operations
• Relationships:
o Integrates with → EHR: Shares administrative patient data o Runs on → VM Host Cluster: For reliability o Used by → Administrative staff
Billing System
• Function: Manages patient billing, insurance claims, payments
• Relationships:
o Integrates with → EHR: Receives service information for billing o Requires → Data Encryption: For financial data protection o Protected by → Data Loss Prevention: To prevent leakage of sensitive financial information
Scheduling System
• Function: Manages appointments, staff scheduling, resource allocation
• Relationships:
o Integrates with → EHR: For patient appointment management o Used by → Clinical and administrative staff o Accessible via → Mobile Devices: For on-the-go schedule management
Analytics Platform
• Function: Provides business intelligence, clinical analytics, reporting
• Relationships:
o Accesses → EHR, HIS: For data analysis o Runs on → VM Host Cluster: For processing power o Protected by → Access Control: For sensitive data protection
API Gateway
• Function: Centralizes API management, provides unified interface to applications
• Relationships:
o Accessed via → Core Network: Central access point o Integrates with → Clinical Applications, Administrative Applications o Protected by → Firewalls, Access Control: Securing API endpoints o Monitored by → Security Information & Event Management: For suspicious activity detection
